questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 1:1-29 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of Moses' recounting of past failures.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the LORD' (v. 3, 10, 20) and the emphasis on God's presence
Pay attention to the phrase 'this generation' (v. 22) and the contrast with the previous generation
Listen for the weight of Moses' words about the spies' report (v. 16-20) and the people's fear

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being addressed, WHAT the new generation must do, WHERE this happens, and WHY Moses is recounting this history.
tips: Include the appointment of judges and leaders (v. 1-13)
Note the sending of spies and the people's refusal to enter the promised land (v. 16-22)
Mention God's promise that the current generation will see the land (v. 24-25)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the appointment of leaders (v. 1-13), the spies' report (v. 16-20), or the people's fear (v. 22-25)?
tips: The phrase 'the LORD is with you' (v. 3) shows God's presence and the new generation's responsibility
The spies' fearful report (v. 20) highlights the danger of unbelief and the cost of fear
The promise to Caleb and Joshua (v. 24) is a model of faith and leadership

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites through this passage?
tips: Moses is teaching the new generation to trust God's promises despite past failures
He emphasizes that leadership must be delegated to avoid the repetition of the previous generation's mistakes
The main point is that God's faithfulness endures even when the people choose to disobey

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'this generation' (v. 22), the meaning of 'the LORD is with you' (v. 3), or the consequence of the people's unbelief (v. 24-25)?
tips: The term 'generation' (in Hebrew: 'genizah') refers to a group of people who share a common experience and are held accountable for their choices
The phrase 'the LORD is with you' (v. 3) is a promise of divine presence and protection, but the context shows that the people must still act
The consequence of the people's unbelief (v. 24) is that they will not see the land, which is a direct result of their fear and lack of trust

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this passage to your life this week? Consider the theme of leadership delegation and trust in God's promises.
tips: Identify one area where you are trying to lead without delegating (like Moses' role) and consider handing it over to someone else
Reflect on a promise God has made to you and how you can trust Him even when it seems costly
Pray for courage to trust God in a situation where you are afraid to take the next step

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of God's faithfulness despite failure.
tips: Thank God for His promises to the new generation, even when the previous generation failed
Ask for the courage to trust God's leadership in your life
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you delegate and trust God's timing

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 2:1-23 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'they lacked nothing' (v.18) and the refusal of Sihon (v.10).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'God' as the provider throughout the chapter
Pay attention to the phrase 'they lacked nothing' in verse 18 which shows divine provision
The emotional tone of trust in God's provision as the Israelites wander

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters in the context of the new generation of Israelites.
tips: Include the 40 years of wandering in the wilderness
Note the complete destruction of Sihon's cities (v.22)
Mention the three nations God forbade attacking: Edom, Moab, and Ammon

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the phrase 'they lacked nothing' (v.18), Sihon's refusal (v.10), or God's victory over Sihon (v.11-12).
tips: The phrase 'they lacked nothing' (v.18) shows God's constant provision even in the wilderness
Sihon's refusal and God's immediate response (v.10-11) demonstrates God's power and sovereignty over kings
The complete destruction of Sihon's cities (v.22) shows God's decisive victory

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God's provision and the need for respect toward other nations?
tips: Moses is reminding the new generation that God provided for them in the wilderness and that they must not attack the nations God forbade (Edom, Moab, Ammon)
This passage foreshadows Christ who is the ultimate provider and the one who conquers enemies
The victory over Sihon shows that God will provide victory when the Israelites trust Him

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'they lacked nothing' in the wilderness, why God forbade attacking Edom, Moab, and Ammon, and the complete destruction of cities.
tips: 'They lacked nothing' (v.18) refers to the physical provision (clothes, food, water) without any shortage
God forbade attacking Edom, Moab, and Ammon because these nations were part of the covenant with Abraham and to avoid sin and idolatry
Complete destruction (v.22) means the cities were razed and the inhabitants killed, not just taken over

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, identify a situation where you are in a wilderness (trials) and trust God to provide for you, just as the Israelites trusted in the wilderness.
tips: Consider an area of your life where you feel God is providing for you but you don't see it
Practice gratitude for God's provision in the small things
Ask God to help you trust Him in a specific trial this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for providing for us in the wilderness of life. Ask for courage to trust Him when we face opposition.
tips: Thank God for providing for you in the wilderness (like the Israelites)
Pray for the strength to trust God when others refuse to let you pass
Ask God to help you be like the Israelites who lacked nothing

chapters.chapterTitle: Defeat of Og; Land East of Jordan

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 3:1-28 aloud, paying attention to the description of Og's bed and the condition for the Transjordan tribes.
tips: Notice the phrase 'Og king of Bashan' appears in verse 1 and the description of his giant nature in verse 2
The repeated phrase 'the land' (Hebrew: 'eretz') emphasizes the territory being taken
Moses' plea for entry and God's refusal (verses 26-27) has a tense emotional quality

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Israel) does WHAT (defeats Og and takes 60 fortified cities), WHERE (the land east of Jordan), and WHY (to secure the land for the new generation of Israelites).
tips: Include that Og was the last of the Rephaim giants (verse 2)
Note the condition for Reuben, Gad, and half-Manasseh: they must fight alongside the other tribes (verses 24-25)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Og's enormous bed (verse 2), the condition for the Transjordan tribes (verses 24-25), or Moses' final charge to Joshua (verse 28).
tips: Og's bed being enormous (13 feet long and 6 feet wide) highlights the scale of the giants they defeated
The condition that the tribes must fight alongside the brothers shows the importance of unity in the new generation
Moses' final words to Joshua: 'be strong and courageous' (verse 28) is a powerful call to leadership

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God through this passage?
tips: Moses emphasizes that God has already secured the Transjordan land for the tribes, but the new generation must be ready to fight and live in unity
He also reminds them that he cannot enter Canaan, setting up Joshua as the leader for the next generation
This passage shows God's faithfulness in providing land and leadership, even when the current leader (Moses) is not able to enter the land

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The description of the Rephaim, the condition for the Transjordan tribes, and why Moses cannot enter Canaan.
tips: Rephaim were a race of giants in the ancient Near East; Og was their last king
The condition ensures that the Transjordan tribes do not become a separate military force and that the whole nation remains united
Moses' inability to enter Canaan is a reminder of his past failure at Meribah (Numbers 20), but the text here shows God's sovereignty in the next generation

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be a leader in your community with the same spirit of unity that Moses described for Reuben, Gad, and half-Manasseh?
tips: Think about a time when you were part of a group that needed to work together for a common goal
Consider how you can be a leader without taking the lead (like the Transjordan tribes) and still be part of the team

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Ask God for the unity and courage to be a leader in your life and community, as modeled by the Transjordan tribes.
tips: Ask God to help you be a leader who unites others in the work of God
Pray for the strength to be courageous in the face of challenges, as Joshua was charged to be

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 4:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the new generation and the previous generation.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'you have seen no form' (v.23)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of warning and hope in verses 23-24

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Moses) is speaking to, WHAT (the laws of God), WHERE (the border of the Promised Land), and WHY (to avoid scattering and experience God's mercy).
tips: Include the new generation of Israelites
Note the contrast between the old generation who saw no form at Sinai and the new generation
Describe the consequence of disobedience: scattering among nations

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the warning about idols (v.15-19), the consequence of corruption (v.23), or the call to seek God with all your heart (v.31).
tips: The phrase 'you have seen no form, only heard a voice' (v.23) emphasizes that God is not a physical being
The promise that if they seek God with all their heart, He will be found (v.31) is a hopeful contrast to the warning
The declaration that God is 'merciful' and 'incomparable' (v.32) is a powerful affirmation of His character

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God's laws and their relationship with Him?
tips: The new generation must not make idols because they have only heard God's voice (v.23)
Obedience leads to God's presence and mercy, while disobedience leads to scattering (v.23-24)
God's law is the most righteous and near, so they must obey to experience His mercy

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The idea that God is not seen but only heard, the concept of 'scattering', and the incomparable nature of God's law.
tips: 'Saw no form' refers to the fact that at Sinai, the Israelites did not see God's physical form, only heard His voice (v.23)
'Scattered among the nations' means being lost without God's guidance and protection, leading to exile
The law is 'incomparable' because it is the most righteous and God is the closest, unlike any other nation's gods

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the call to seek God with all your heart (v.31) this week? What idol (false belief or practice) might you need to abandon?
tips: Identify one area where you might be 'corrupting' yourself by following false idols
Practice seeking God with all your heart by spending time in prayer and Scripture
Ask God to help you avoid scattering by staying close to Him

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His mercy and ask for the courage to seek Him with all your heart.
tips: Thank God for the promise that He will be found if we seek Him with all our hearts
Pray for the strength to avoid the scattering that comes from disobedience
Ask God to help you live according to His incomparable law

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 5:1-21 aloud, paying attention to the emotional shift from the people's terror to the weight of the commandments.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the LORD' (v.6) and the emphasis on fear (v.1-3)
Pay attention to the phrase 'you shall not' (v.10, 11, 15, 16, 17, 19) which appears multiple times
The emotional tone starts with terror (v.1-3) and moves to the solemnity of the commandments (v.4-21)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Moses and the new generation) is being taught, WHAT (the Ten Commandments) is being restated, WHERE (Horeb, Mount Sinai) it occurs, and WHY (to renew the covenant and ensure obedience in the Promised Land).
tips: Include Moses recalling the event at Horeb where the people were terrified (v.1-3)
Note that God restates the commandments to the new generation (v.4-21)
Highlight the purpose: to prepare the people for the land with a heart that fears God

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the people's terror (v.1-3), the restatement of the commandments (v.6-21), or the role of Moses as the only mediator (v.21)?
tips: The phrase 'the LORD has chosen you' (v.2) shows God's active involvement and the new generation's special status
The repetition of 'you shall not' (v.10, 11, 15, 16, 17, 19) emphasizes the severity of sin and the need for constant obedience
Moses' role as the mediator (v.21) highlights the need for a human intermediary between God and the people

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God and their relationship through this passage?
tips: Moses is renewing the covenant by restating the Ten Commandments to ensure the new generation understands the cost of obedience
The theme of 'healthy fear of God' (v.1-3) is critical for avoiding the pitfalls of the land they are entering
The need for a mediator (Moses) foreshadows the greater need for Christ as the ultimate mediator

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The restatement of the commandments, the role of Moses as the only mediator, or the concept of 'fear of God'?
tips: The term 'fear' (Hebrew: yirah) here does not mean terror but reverence and awe, which is necessary for obedience
In ancient Israel, the commandments were given in the context of a covenant that required a mediator (Moses) to interpret
The Ten Commandments are a restatement of the old covenant, emphasizing the continuity of God's requirements

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the need for a mediator (as in Moses) apply to your life? What can you do this week to cultivate a heart that fears God and obeys?
tips: Consider one area where you need a mediator (like a trusted friend or spiritual leader) to help you obey
Practice 'healthy fear' by reflecting on God's commands and how they affect your decisions
This week, choose one commandment (e.g., 'do not steal') and take a step to obey it with intention

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the mediator (Moses) and for Christ as the greater mediator. Ask for a heart that fears God and obeys.
tips: Thank God for the mediator (Moses) who brought the law and for Christ as the ultimate mediator
Ask for a heart that fears God and is willing to obey the Ten Commandments
Pray for courage to face situations where you need to be a mediator for others

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 6:4-9 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'with all your...' and the phrase 'the LORD is one'.
tips: Notice the threefold command: 'with all your heart, with all your soul, with all your might' (v.5)
The phrase 'the LORD is one' (v.4) is a declaration of monotheism
The repetition of 'write' in verses 6-8 emphasizes the importance of practical memorization

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the new generation of Israelites) is commanded to do WHAT (love God with all their heart, soul, and might) WHERE (in the wilderness, at the border of the Promised Land) and WHY (to prevent forgetting God in prosperity and to ensure the next generation knows the one true God).
tips: Include the command to teach children (v.7)
Note the practical instructions: writing on doorposts and foreheads (v.8)
The context of the new generation entering the land and facing prosperity

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the declaration of God's oneness (v.4), the threefold command to love (v.5), or the practical application of teaching and writing (v.6-9)?
tips: The phrase 'the LORD is one' (v.4) is a radical claim that sets the foundation for all other commands
The threefold command in v.5 shows that love for God must be total and without reservation
The practical instructions (v.6-9) show how to internalize the commandment in daily life

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God through this passage?
tips: Moses emphasizes that the new generation must have a personal, unwavering devotion to the one true God
This passage addresses the risk of idolatry in prosperity (when they have the land and resources) by requiring constant remembrance
The command to teach children ensures the covenant is passed on through generations

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The command to love God with all your might? How does the one God concept relate to the Israelites' past? The practical application of writing on doorposts?
tips: 'The LORD is one' (v.4) contrasts with the polytheistic context of Canaan, where gods were many and interchangeable
'Love with all your might' (v.5) implies a love that is not just emotional but includes actions and sacrifice
The instruction to write on doorposts and foreheads (v.8) shows that God's command must be visible and constant in the home and public spaces

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This passage emphasizes teaching the next generation. What specific way can you teach someone about the importance of God in their daily life this week?
tips: Choose one person to share a short story about how God has been present in their life
Write a note on a doorpost (a physical object) to remind them of God's love
Practice teaching by asking a question that leads to reflection on God

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being the one true God and for loving us with all our hearts. Ask for help to avoid forgetting Him in prosperity.
tips: Thank God for the declaration of His oneness and for the command to love Him completely
Pray for strength to teach others about Him in a world that often forgets
Ask God to help you keep the command to love Him with all your heart even when life is prosperous

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 7:1-25 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'I have chosen you' (v.7), the repetition of 'you shall not' (v.3-4, 5-6), and the contrast between God's election and the nations' actions.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I have chosen you' (v.7) emphasizes God's unilateral choice
Pay attention to the list of prohibitions in verses 3-4: no intermarriage, no treaties
The phrase 'for your sake' (v.7) shows God's love for Israel

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God is addressing, WHAT He commands, WHERE this applies (Canaan), and WHY (to avoid idolatry and maintain holiness).
tips: The new generation of Israelites entering Canaan
The seven nations of Canaan and the command to destroy them completely
The election of Israel by God's love, not their merit

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's election by grace (v.7), the warning against intermarriage (v.3-4), or the reminder of God's victory over Egypt (v.20-25)?
tips: 'I have chosen you in love' (v.7) - this contrasts with the nations' actions and shows God's initiative
The command 'you shall not make treaties' (v.4) because the nations are untrustworthy
The phrase 'I am the Lord your God' (v.7) emphasizes the covenant relationship

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God's election and their holiness?
tips: Moses warns that Israel's identity is not based on their strength but on God's love and oath to the patriarchs
This passage establishes the foundation for Israel's distinctiveness and holiness in Canaan
The election is a gift, not a result of merit, so they must avoid the nations' sins

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The command to destroy the nations (v.1-2), the concept of 'elected by grace' (v.7), or the warning against intermarriage (v.3-4)?
tips: The phrase 'destroy' (v.1-2) is not about genocide but about removing the nations' influence and idolatry
'Elected by grace' means God chose them before time, not because they were righteous or strong
Intermarriage with the Canaanites (v.3-4) is a warning to avoid assimilation and idolatry

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the theme of being chosen by God's love (not merit) apply to your life this week?
tips: Consider a situation where you feel you have earned something, but God's love is the foundation
Think about how to avoid 'intermarriage' with worldly values that compromise your faith
Pray for courage to live holy in the midst of a mixed culture

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that you are chosen by His love, not your actions. Ask for the strength to live in holiness.
tips: Thank God that you are chosen by His love, not your actions
Ask for the strength to resist the temptation to make treaties with worldly values
Pray for the grace to avoid the sins of the nations and live in holiness

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 8:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between God's discipline in the wilderness and the promise of the good land.
tips: Notice the phrase 'man does not live by bread alone' (v.3)
Pay attention to the metaphor of God disciplining as a father (v.5)
The repeated command 'remember the LORD' (v.1-2, 11)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God tested, WHAT the testing involved, WHERE it happened, and WHY he did it.
tips: The 40 years of wilderness wandering (v.2)
God's discipline as a father (v.5)
The promise of the good land (v.7-10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the phrase 'man does not live by bread alone' (v.3), the discipline as a father (v.5), or the promise of the good land (v.7-10)?
tips: The contrast between physical sustenance and spiritual life in v.3 is timeless
The metaphor of God disciplining as a father (v.5) shows His love and care
The promise of the land (v.7) is a tangible reminder of God's faithfulness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God through this passage of the wilderness testing?
tips: The new generation must not forget God's discipline when they enter the land
This passage teaches that God's word is the true sustenance for life (v.3)
The land is a gift, but without God, it is worthless

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'man does not live by bread alone'? Why God disciplined them as a father? What does 'good land' mean?
tips: 'Man does not live by bread alone' is a Hebrew idiom meaning that physical food alone is insufficient for life; it points to spiritual sustenance
The discipline as a father is not punishment but teaching and care, as seen in the wilderness journey
'Good land' refers to the land of Canaan, which God promises to be abundant in water, grain, and minerals

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you remember God in your daily life, especially when you feel satisfied with your circumstances?
tips: When you have success or abundance, pause and recall the wilderness journey (v.1-2)
Practice gratitude for God's discipline as a father (v.5)
Ask yourself: 'What part of my life requires me to remember God as the true sustainer?'

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His discipline in the wilderness and ask for help to remember Him in the land we have.
tips: Thank God for disciplining you as a father to teach you
Pray for the new generation to not forget God
Ask God to keep you from the danger of forgetting Him when you have the land

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 9:1-28 aloud, focusing on the sequence of events from the golden calf incident to Moses' intercession.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I have seen' (v. 1) and 'you are stubborn' (v. 6)
Pay attention to the phrase 'not because of righteousness' (v. 5)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Israelites) is tested, WHAT (Moses recounts their rebellion), WHERE (the wilderness, specifically Horeb), and WHY (to warn the new generation that the land is not given by their righteousness).
tips: Include the golden calf incident (v. 1-7)
Note the forty days of intercession (v. 18-20)
Mention God's relenting because of Moses' prayer (v. 20-21)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the golden calf incident (v. 1-7), Moses' intercession (v. 18-20), or God's response to Moses' prayer (v. 20-21)?
tips: The golden calf incident shows the Israelites' immediate idolatry after the Exodus
Moses' intercession for forty days demonstrates the cost of obedience
God's relenting shows mercy is not earned but given through prayer

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation about God's covenant and their standing in the land?
tips: The land is not given because of their righteousness (v. 5)
The new generation must understand their stubbornness (v. 6)
God's mercy is secured by intercession, not human merit

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'not because of righteousness' (v. 5), the concept of 'stubbornness' (v. 6), or the forty days of intercession (v. 18-20)?
tips: 'Not because of righteousness' means the land is given by God's grace, not the Israelites' moral standing
'Stubbornness' (Hebrew: 'kānāh') refers to persistent refusal to change, not temporary rebellion
The forty days of intercession shows the depth of Moses' pleading for God's mercy

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Recognize that you are not righteous and that God's inheritance is secured by His grace through Christ's intercession. What area of your life needs to be surrendered to God's mercy this week?
tips: Consider an area where you are trying to earn God's favor
Pray for humility to accept that you are not righteous
Practice the intercessory heart of Moses by praying for God's mercy

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He gives the land not because of our righteousness but because of His mercy. Ask for humility to recognize our sin and courage to trust in Christ's intercession.
tips: Thank God for the land (the promise) given by grace
Pray for the new generation to understand they are not righteous
Ask Christ to be the intercessor for your sins

chapters.chapterTitle: New Tablets and What God Requires

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 10:1-27 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'circumcise your hearts' in verse 16 and the call to 'love the sojourner' in verse 16.
tips: Notice the phrase 'circumcise your hearts' (v.16) is a call for inner transformation
Pay attention to the contrast between God's love for the patriarchs and the current generation's responsibility
The emotional tone shifts from the failure of the first tablets to the hope of a renewed covenant

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being instructed, WHAT God requires, WHERE this happens, and WHY Moses is writing this passage.
tips: Include the new tablets (v.1-5) and the setting apart of Levi for the ark (v.8-10)
Note the call to fear the LORD, walk in His ways, love Him, and serve with all heart and soul (v.12-13)
Describe the reason: to ensure the new generation follows God's law without repeating the sin of the golden calf

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the phrase 'circumcise your hearts' (v.16), the call to 'love the sojourner' (v.16), or God's statement about being Lord of heaven and earth (v.14).
tips: 'Circumcise your hearts' (v.16) is a powerful call to inner change that resonates with the Christian concept of the Spirit's work
'Love the sojourner' (v.16) shows God's concern for the marginalized and is a practical application for today
God's statement in verse 14: 'God is Lord of heaven and earth, yet He loved the patriarchs and chose their descendants' highlights the depth of God's covenant love

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God's covenant and their responsibilities?
tips: Moses is reminding the new generation that God has made a new covenant through the tablets and that they must live by faith and obedience
The passage emphasizes that God's love for the patriarchs (Abraham, Isaac, Jacob) is the foundation for the new generation to follow the law
This sets the stage for the Mosaic Law as a living covenant that requires inner transformation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'new tablets', the phrase 'circumcise your hearts', and the call to 'love the sojourner'.
tips: 'New tablets' (v.1-5) refers to the second set of tablets that God wrote after the golden calf incident (Exodus 32-34)
'Circumcise your hearts' (v.16) is a metaphor for inner transformation, not physical circumcision
'Love the sojourner' (v.16) means to love foreigners and the marginalized, which is a unique command in the context of ancient Israel

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you 'circumcise your hearts' (v.16) this week to better love the sojourner?
tips: Identify one area where you need to change your heart (e.g., forgiveness, generosity, or trust in God)
Take a concrete step to love a sojourner this week (e.g., help a neighbor, visit someone in need)
Pray for the Spirit to help you transform your heart as you live in community

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His covenant love and ask for the strength to 'circumcise your hearts' and love the sojourner.
tips: Thank God for His love that chooses the patriarchs and calls us to follow His ways
Pray for courage to love the sojourner in your community
Ask God to help you transform your heart through the Spirit's work

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 11:1-32 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between Egypt and the promised land in verses 24-28 and the repetition of 'choose life' in verses 21-22.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the heavens will close' (v.29) as a vivid image of divine judgment
Pay attention to the repetition of 'love the LORD' and 'keep His commandments' in verse 1
The command to write the law on doorposts (v.22) is a practical application for daily life

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the new generation of Israelites) is being instructed, WHAT (to love God and obey His law), WHERE (in the wilderness before entering the promised land), and WHY (because the land's fertility depends on God's rain and they must choose blessing or curse).
tips: Include the three key events: seeing God's deeds in Egypt, crossing the Red Sea, and wilderness discipline
Note that the promised land is not self-sustaining like Egypt (with irrigation) but requires God's rain
The consequence of obedience (rain) versus disobedience (heavens closing) is central

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the contrast between Egypt and the promised land (vv.24-28), the call to write the law on doorposts (v.22), or the choice between life and death (v.21)?
tips: The phrase 'the heavens will close' (v.29) is a powerful image of God's judgment that resonates with the severity of disobedience
The command to teach children and bind the law as signs (v.22) shows the importance of intergenerational teaching and practical application
The choice between blessing (obedience) and curse (disobedience) in v.21 is a timeless reminder of our choices

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God through this passage?
tips: Moses is emphasizing that the new generation must choose to love God and obey His law because the promised land's fertility depends on God's provision (rain)
The chapter sets up a covenant relationship: obedience leads to blessing (rain), disobedience leads to curse (heavens closing)
This passage foreshadows how spiritual life depends on God's grace, not human effort (as in Egypt)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of the land depending on rain? The meaning of 'heavens closing'? Why the emphasis on teaching children?
tips: The phrase 'the promised land is not like Egypt with irrigation' (v.24) might be confusing because Egypt had rivers; clarify that the promised land requires divine rain (not human irrigation) for crop
'Heavens closing' (v.29) is a metaphor for God withdrawing His blessings (like drought or famine) but in a spiritual sense, it means the curse of disobedience
Writing the law on doorposts (v.22) was a practical way to have the law visible in the home, which was unusual for nomadic cultures

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'the land depends on God's rain' to your spiritual life this week? Specifically, how do you trust God to provide for your needs when circumstances seem dry?
tips: Identify one area where you feel like you're in a 'dry season' (e.g., lack of spiritual growth, financial struggles) and pray for God's rain (provision) through faith
Write one key verse from Deuteronomy 11 on a piece of paper and place it where you see it daily (like a doorpost) to remind you of God's provision
Share your faith in God's provision with one person this week, just as the Israelites were to teach their children

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the promise of His provision (like rain) and ask for the courage to choose obedience when it's difficult.
tips: Thank God for the promise of His provision in your life
Ask for the courage to choose obedience in a situation where it's challenging
Pray for the wisdom to teach others the truth of God's word, just as Moses instructed

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 12:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the repeated command 'you shall not' and the contrast between pagan practices and God's chosen place.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'you shall not' (vv. 1, 5, 8, 9, 11, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 20, 22, 23, 24)
Pay attention to the contrast between Canaanite practices and the new worship (vv. 2, 3, 4)
Emotional tone: Urgent command to avoid idolatry and centralize worship

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Israelites) does WHAT (destroys pagan worship sites and chooses one place for worship) WHERE (in the land of Canaan) and WHY (to avoid idolatry and establish proper worship of the LORD).
tips: Include the destruction of Canaanite altars and Asherah poles (v. 2)
Note the command to seek the place God chooses (v. 3, 5)
Mention the prohibition of blood (v. 7, 8)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the destruction of pagan sites (v. 2), the command to choose one place (v. 3), or the blood prohibition (v. 7)?
tips: The destruction of pagan sites shows a decisive break from idolatry (v. 2)
The command to seek the place God chooses (v. 3) emphasizes God's active choice and the Israelites' response
The blood prohibition (v. 7) is a clear sign of the new covenant and separation from pagan practices

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God through this passage?
tips: Moses is emphasizing that God alone is to be worshipped in one central location to avoid idolatry and to maintain the covenant
This central worship is a sign of God's sovereignty and the Israelites' unity in worship
The passage also sets the foundation for the temple worship that would come later

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The destruction of all pagan sites, the blood prohibition, or the requirement to choose one place?
tips: The destruction of all pagan sites (v. 2) is a command to eliminate all idolatrous practices, which might seem harsh but was necessary for the new covenant
The blood prohibition (v. 7) is a sign that the Israelites are to live in a new way, distinct from pagan practices where blood was consumed
The requirement to choose one place for worship (v. 3) might be confusing because the Israelites were in a land that had many places of worship, but Moses is emphasizing God's unique choice

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of centralized worship. What can you do this week to ensure your worship is focused on God in one place (e.g., a specific church, prayer group) rather than scattered?
tips: Consider where you are worshiping and whether it's the only place you attend
Think about how you can avoid mixing worship practices (like blood in your food)
Pray for the courage to follow God's command to choose one place for worship

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the command to worship in one place. Ask for the strength to avoid idolatry and to seek God's chosen place.
tips: Thank God for providing a place of worship that is central and pure
Pray for the guidance to choose the right place for worship
Ask God to help you avoid the practices of the world (like blood in your food)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 14:1-15 aloud, focusing on the list of clean animals (vv. 3-19) and the tithe instructions (vv. 23-28).

Pay attention to the phrase 'eat nothing found dead' (v. 21) as a warning against contamination
Notice the emphasis on 'the LORD' in the tithe commands (v. 23)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe who (the Israelites), what (the laws about clean/unclean food and tithes), where (in the land of Israel), and why (to maintain holiness and provide for the vulnerable).
tips: Include the distinction between clean and unclean animals (vv. 3-19)
Note the annual tithe requirement (vv. 23-24)
Mention the triennial tithe for the Levites, foreigners, widows, and orphans (vv. 25-28)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the list of clean animals (vv. 3-19), the command to eat nothing found dead (v. 21), or the tithe for the vulnerable (vv. 25-28)?
tips: The detailed list of clean animals (vv. 3-19) shows God's care for the Israelites' dietary practices
The command 'eat nothing found dead' (v. 21) highlights the seriousness of avoiding contamination
The tithe for the vulnerable (vv. 25-28) demonstrates God's provision for the poor and marginalized

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about their identity as God's holy people through these laws?
tips: The laws distinguish Israel from the nations (as in Leviticus 11)
The tithe system ensures care for the vulnerable, showing God's concern for the poor
This passage reinforces that the Israelites are holy and must live by God's laws to maintain their relationship with Him

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The distinction between clean and unclean animals? The tithe requirements? The cultural context of the time?
tips: The list of clean animals (vv. 3-19) is extensive and may be confusing without context from Leviticus 11
The annual tithe (vv. 23-24) and triennial tithe (vv. 25-28) have different purposes and timing
In ancient Israel, the concept of 'the chosen place' (v. 23) for tithing was specific to the temple location

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the care for the vulnerable (vv. 25-28) this week?
tips: Identify one person in your life who is vulnerable (widow, orphan, foreigner) and check in with them
Consider giving a tithe (as a percentage of your income) to support the vulnerable
Pray for the church to be a place where the vulnerable are cared for, as modeled in this passage

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the theme of God's care for the vulnerable and the holiness of the Israelites.
tips: Thank God for providing the laws that protect and care for the vulnerable
Ask for the strength to live as a holy people and to care for those in need
Pray for the church to be a place where the vulnerable are welcomed and supported

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 15:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the conditional language and the phrase 'do not harden your heart'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'if' and 'when' in the conditions for debt release
Pay attention to the phrase 'do not harden your heart' (v.9) which shows the emotional tone of concern
The phrase 'do not let him go empty-handed' (v.11) is a key phrase of generosity

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Israelites), WHAT (debt release and generosity), WHERE (in Israel), WHEN (every seventh year), and WHY (to prevent poverty and ensure God's care).
tips: Include the three key elements: debt release in the seventh year, the poor, and the Hebrew servants
Note that the passage commands the Israelites to be generous even when they are poor
The firstborn belong to the LORD (v.18) is a reminder of God's ownership

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the debt release (v.1-2), the call for generosity (v.5-7), the provision for servants (v.8-11), or the ownership of firstborn (v.12-18)?
tips: The phrase 'do not harden your heart' (v.9) shows the emotional weight of the command to be generous
The provision of food for the servant going free (v.11) is a tangible example of love in action
The declaration that firstborn belong to the LORD (v.18) ties the theme to covenant and God's ownership

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about the Sabbath year and generosity?
tips: Moses is emphasizing that God's law is designed to ensure that poverty is not a permanent condition in Israel
The Sabbath year is a sign of God's provision and care for His people, especially the vulnerable
This passage foreshadows the Christian concept of the Jubilee (Liberation from sin's debt)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The scope of debt release, the definition of 'poor', or the practice of freeing servants?
tips: Debt release in the seventh year (v.1-2) applies only to debts among Israelites, not to foreign debtors
The term 'poor' (v.5) is not defined by poverty of wealth but by the condition of being in need of help
The requirement to provide generously (v.7) is challenging because it requires the community to be generous even when they are poor

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of generosity in the Sabbath year. What can you do this week to be generous to someone in need, as the Israelites were commanded to do?
tips: Consider giving to a neighbor who is struggling (like the poor in the passage)
Think about how you can provide for someone going free (like the Hebrew servant) by giving them a meaningful gift
Avoid hardening your heart (v.9) by being attentive to the needs of others

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the Sabbath year and the promise of freedom. Ask for courage to be generous and not harden your heart.
tips: Thank God for the Sabbath year and the promise of freedom
Pray for the courage to give generously when it's difficult
Ask God to help you see others as the poor in need and to be generous in your life

questions.title: Read Aloud

tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'three times a year' (v.1) to emphasize the regularity of the feasts
Pay attention to the emphasis on 'all males' (v.1) and the requirement to bring offerings without being empty-handed (v.14)
The phrase 'the LORD your God' (v.3) appears multiple times to highlight the personal relationship

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Israelites) does WHAT (appears before the LORD at the chosen place three times a year), WHERE (at the chosen place, which is the temple in Jerusalem), and WHY (to remember God's deliverance from Egypt, to give thanks for blessings, and to pursue justice).
tips: Include the three feasts: Passover and Unleavened Bread (v.1-2), Feast of Weeks (v.9-10), and Feast of Tabernacles (v.13-14)
Note the command to give offerings without being empty-handed (v.14)
Mention the prohibition against setting up Asherahs or pillars (v.15)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the connection between the feasts and God's deliverance (v.1-2), the requirement to give as God has blessed (v.14), or the command to appoint judges and officials (v.18-19).
tips: The phrase 'remembering the day the LORD your God brought you out of Egypt' (v.2) is powerful because it ties the feasts to the Exodus
The instruction to give 'as God has blessed' (v.14) shows that giving is a response to God's provision, not a burden
The call to 'pursue justice' (v.18-19) is a practical application that continues throughout the year

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God and their relationship with Him through these feasts?
tips: Moses is teaching the new generation that God's covenant is maintained through regular, public worship and obedience
The feasts are not just rituals but reminders of God's faithfulness and the need for active participation in justice
This passage sets the foundation for the Israelites to live as a community of faith that is both worshipful and just

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The requirement for all males to appear three times a year, the meaning of 'giving as God has blessed', and the prohibition against Asherahs and pillars.
tips: The command for all males to appear (v.1) might seem burdensome, but it is a communal practice to ensure the people are united in worship
The phrase 'giving as God has blessed' (v.14) refers to giving from one's own resources, not a fixed amount, which can be confusing in modern contexts
Asherahs and pillars were fertility idols in Canaan; the prohibition (v.15) shows that Israel must avoid pagan practices

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'giving as God has blessed' this week?
tips: Consider an area where you have been blessed by God and how you can give generously without hesitation
Think about the importance of community: how can you share your blessings with others in your community?
Practically, this week, make a small offering to someone in need or a church fellowship that aligns with your blessings

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His provision and ask for the courage to live in obedience.
tips: Thank God for the three feasts that remind us of His deliverance and provision
Ask for the strength to give generously from what He has blessed you with
Pray for the community to pursue justice and avoid idolatry

chapters.chapterTitle: Levites and the Prophet Like Moses

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 18:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the Levites' role and the prohibited practices.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the LORD is your portion' (v.1) repeated for emphasis
Pay attention to the list of abominations: child sacrifice, divination, sorcery, mediums (v.20-22)
Notice the phrase 'a prophet like Moses' (v.18) and the test of prophecy (v.20)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the Levites are, WHAT they do, WHERE this applies, and WHY Moses gives these instructions to the new generation.
tips: Include the Levites having no land inheritance (v.1-3)
Note the Levites eat the offerings (v.3-4)
Describe the prohibited practices: child sacrifice, divination, sorcery, mediums (v.20-22)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Levites' role without land (v.1), the prohibition of occult practices (v.20-22), or the test of prophecy (v.20).
tips: The Levites' role: 'the LORD is your portion' shows God's provision without land inheritance
The prohibition of child sacrifice and divination: these are abominations that the new generation must avoid to stay faithful
The test of prophecy: if the words don't come true, it's not from God — this is a practical way to discern truth

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God's provision and leadership?
tips: The Levites are God's chosen servants without land, so they are a living testimony to God's care
The new generation must avoid idolatry and false prophets, and trust in God's promised prophet (like Moses)
This sets up the covenant that God's word is reliable and will be fulfilled

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The Levites' role without land, the meaning of 'prophet like Moses', or how to test a prophet?
tips: The Levites have no land inheritance because they are set apart for worship and service to God, not for land ownership
A 'prophet like Moses' refers to one who speaks God's word with authority and clarity, similar to Moses' role in delivering the law
The test of prophecy (v.20) means that if the prophet's words don't come true, they are not from God — this is a practical way to avoid false teachings

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, identify one false teaching or practice in your life that you need to avoid (like occult practices) and pray for the Holy Spirit to help you discern true prophets.
tips: Consider an area where you're holding back from full obedience to God
Think about something precious you need to surrender to God (like the Levites' role as a testimony)
Practice discernment by checking if a message or person's words come true

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the Levites as a living example of His provision and ask for the courage to reject false teachings.
tips: Thank God for the Levites who are His chosen people without land
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you discern God's true voice
Ask God to give you the courage to trust the true prophet (Christ) and avoid false prophets

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 19:1-21 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'set apart three cities of refuge' (v.1), the requirement for two or three witnesses (v.15), and the boundary markers (v.20).
tips: Note the repetition of 'refuge' in the context of protection from blood vengeance
Pay attention to the phrase 'a single witness is insufficient' (v.15) as it emphasizes the need for multiple witnesses
Notice the emphasis on boundary markers not being moved (v.20) to ensure the cities remain accessible

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Moses) is establishing the cities, WHAT (the cities of refuge for unintentional killers), WHERE (in the land of Israel), and WHY (to protect the innocent from blood vengeance).
tips: Include the requirement that the land must expand and add cities (v.1-2)
Note the need for two or three witnesses to convict a murderer (v.15-16)
Describe the punishment for false witnesses (v.20)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the establishment of the cities of refuge (v.1), the two-witness rule (v.15), or the punishment for false witnesses (v.20).
tips: The cities of refuge show God's care for the innocent in a society where blood vengeance is common
The two-witness rule is a practical and just standard that prevents wrongful conviction
The punishment for false witnesses ensures that the system of justice is honest and not easily manipulated

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about the need for a system of justice that protects the innocent from blood vengeance?
tips: The new generation will face challenges in the land and need a safe place for unintentional killers
This system shows that God is the ultimate judge and not the blood feud
The cities of refuge are a divine solution to a problem that was common in the ancient world

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of cities of refuge, the requirement for two or three witnesses, and the punishment for false witnesses.
tips: The cities of refuge were a practical solution to blood vengeance in a land that was expanding (v.1-2)
The boundary markers must not be moved to prevent disputes over the cities (v.20)
False witnesses are punished by the same law they intended for the accused (v.20) to maintain justice

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be a safe place for others in your community when you face the possibility of being falsely accused?
tips: Be intentional about the people you trust to witness in your life (like having two or three people who can vouch for you)
When you are accused, seek multiple witnesses to ensure justice
Practice the principle of setting boundaries for your actions to prevent false accusations

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the cities of refuge as a picture of Christ, our refuge from condemnation. Ask for the strength to be a witness for truth and to avoid false accusations in your relationships.
tips: Thank God for providing Jesus as the ultimate refuge from condemnation
Pray for courage to be a witness for truth in your community
Ask God to help you avoid the false accusations that come from pride or misunderstanding

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 20:1-20 aloud, focusing on the priest's encouragement in verses 1-2, the exemptions for the fainthearted in verses 3-4, and the command to destroy the Canaanite nations in verses 7-10.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the Lord is with you' in verse 1
Pay attention to the phrase 'fainthearted' (v. 4) which describes those who lack courage
Listen for the contrast between 'destroy' (v. 16) and 'do not destroy fruit trees' (v. 19)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the new generation of Israelites are, WHAT the priest commands, WHERE the battle is taking place, and WHY these laws are given.
tips: Include that the laws are for the officers to apply exemptions
Note the specific exemption for the fainthearted (v. 4)
Mention the command to destroy the seven Canaanite nations (v. 16)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the priest's encouragement (v. 1-2), the exemptions for the fainthearted (v. 3-4), or the warning about the Canaanite nations (v. 7-10)?
tips: The phrase 'the Lord is with you' (v. 1) provides immediate reassurance before battle
The exemption for the fainthearted (v. 4) shows Moses' care for spiritual vulnerability
The command to destroy the seven nations (v. 16) emphasizes God's holiness and separation from sin

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God through this passage?
tips: Moses ensures they understand God's presence in their battle
He emphasizes the spiritual condition of the people (not being fainthearted)
The passage shows God's requirement for holiness through total destruction of Canaanite nations

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The command to destroy the Canaanite nations, the exemption for the fainthearted, or the exception for fruit trees?
tips: The command to destroy seven nations (v. 16) requires understanding of the Canaanite nations' role in the land
The term 'fainthearted' (v. 4) refers to spiritual weakness, not physical weakness
The exception for fruit trees (v. 19) shows God's concern for practical needs during siege

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's presence and exemption for the fainthearted in your current life?
tips: Identify a situation where you feel 'fainthearted' and ask God for courage
Pray for strength to face challenges knowing God is with you
Consider how you can be vulnerable and seek God's help rather than acting alone

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His presence in your battles and ask for strength to face challenges.
tips: Thank God for being with you in your current struggles
Pray for courage to overcome feelings of being fainthearted
Ask God to help you remember His presence in your battles

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 21:1-23 aloud, paying attention to the ritual of the heifer (v.1-3) and the stoning of a rebellious son (v.18-19).
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the nearest city' (v.1) and the heifer's neck being broken (v.2) as a ritual of atonement
Emotional tone: The laws are practical but also carry weight of divine judgment (e.g., v.22-23 about the hanged person)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT is being commanded, WHERE it applies, and WHY it matters for the new generation of Israelites.
tips: Include the unsolved murder case (v.1-3) and the captive woman's marriage rights (v.15-16)
Note the firstborn's rights (v.17) and the punishment for a rebellious son (v.18-19)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the heifer ritual (v.1-3), the captive woman's rights (v.15-16), or the stoning of a rebellious son (v.18-19)?
tips: The heifer ritual shows a community-wide atonement for bloodguilt without bloodshed (v.2)
The captive woman's right to be married after mourning (v.15) demonstrates God's care for women's dignity
The stoning of a rebellious son (v.19) is a harsh but clear boundary for family order

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about justice, family, and divine order through this passage?
tips: Moses is establishing a legal framework that emphasizes community responsibility (e.g., elders in unsolved murder cases) and divine boundaries (e.g., firstborn's rights)
This passage shows that God's laws are practical for daily life and reflect His concern for the vulnerable (women, children)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The heifer ritual? Why stoning is allowed? The curse on the hanged?
tips: The heifer ritual (v.1-3) is a symbolic atonement for bloodguilt but not a substitute for actual justice
Stoning a rebellious son (v.19) is a severe punishment that requires careful community discernment
The curse on the hanged (v.22-23) is a divine pronouncement that the law of Moses is distinct from the law of the land

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'bloodguilt and atonement' (v.2) to a current situation where you feel guilty or need to seek cleansing?
tips: Think about a time when you've caused harm and how you might seek atonement (like the heifer ritual)
Pray for the community to handle conflicts with grace, as the elders did in unsolved murders

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of divine judgment and cleansing (v.22-23).
tips: Thank God for His cleansing power in the blood of Christ (Gal 3:13)
Ask for courage to face the consequences of sin and to seek cleansing through Christ
Pray for the community to handle conflicts with wisdom and mercy

chapters.chapterTitle: Those Excluded and Included; Miscellaneous Laws

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 23:1-23 aloud, paying attention to the repeated phrase 'he shall be excluded' (v.1) and the contrast between exclusion and inclusion (v.7-8).
tips: Notice the phrase 'he shall be excluded' appears three times (v.1, 2, 3)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is affected by these laws, WHAT the laws require, WHERE they apply (the camp), and WHY (to maintain the assembly's holiness and protect the vulnerable).
tips: Include the exclusion of eunuchs (v.1)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the eunuch's exclusion (v.1), the generational exclusion for Ammonites and Moabites (v.3-4), or the inclusion of Edomites and Egyptians (v.7-8).
tips: The eunuch's exclusion: a clear boundary for holiness (v.1) as they could not reproduce and thus were outside the community
The generational exclusion for Ammonites and Moabites: a strong warning about foreign alliances (v.3-4) because these nations were historically hostile
The inclusion of Edomites and Egyptians: a hopeful note of inclusion despite ethnic barriers (v.7-8) after three generations

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about the assembly and camp holiness through this passage?
tips: The new generation must understand the boundaries of the assembly to maintain the camp's holiness (v.1-13)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The exclusion of eunuchs, the generational limits for Ammonites and Moabites, and the inclusion of Edomites and Egyptians.
tips: Eunuchs were excluded because they could not reproduce and thus were not part of the community's lineage (v.1)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'camp holiness' by protecting the vulnerable this week?
tips: Consider how you can help escaped slaves (v.15) or the vulnerable in your community

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the boundaries that keep the camp holy and ask for courage to include others despite barriers.
tips: Thank God for His boundaries that keep the assembly holy
Pray for courage to include Edomites and Egyptians (like the new generation) despite ethnic barriers
Ask God to protect the vulnerable (escaped slaves) and help you be honest in your dealings

questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 26:1-11 aloud, focusing on the confession and offering details.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I will confess' (v. 2, 4, 5, 7)
Pay attention to the emotional shift from solemn confession to joyful worship (v. 10-11)
The phrase 'the LORD has brought us out of Egypt' (v. 5) is a key expression of deliverance

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is bringing the offering, WHAT they are doing, WHERE it takes place, and WHY they are doing it.
tips: Include the new generation of Israelites
Note the confession of their ancestors' journey from Egypt to the promised land
The purpose: to acknowledge God's deliverance and fulfill covenant obligations

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the historical confession (v. 5), the declaration of tithing (v. 11), or the place of offering (v. 10).
tips: The confession: 'My father was a wandering Aramean...' (v. 5) - deeply personal and historical
The declaration of tithing to the vulnerable (v. 11) - practical application of covenant care
The act of placing the basket before the altar (v. 10) - symbol of worship and covenant renewal

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites through this passage?
tips: Moses is teaching the new generation to remember their history and God's deliverance to maintain their identity and covenant faithfulness
The passage emphasizes that the Israelites are not to forget their origin and the cost of their freedom
This passage shows that God's covenant is rooted in the past and must be lived out in the present through obedience

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The historical confession for a new generation, the concept of firstfruits, or the tithe system?
tips: The new generation has never been in Egypt, so they must confess the story of their ancestors (v. 5) to maintain their identity
Firstfruits in this context is a symbolic act of gratitude and commitment, not just the literal first harvest
The tithe system is a social justice mechanism to ensure care for the vulnerable, and it remains relevant today

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of confession and tithing to your life this week?
tips: Reflect on your own story of deliverance and confess it to God
Consider giving a tithe (or proportional offering) to support the church or a community of the vulnerable
Think about how you can help an orphan, foreigner, or widow in your life this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His deliverance and ask for the courage to live out the covenant.
tips: Thank God for bringing you out of Egypt (spiritual deliverance)
Ask for the courage to confess your history and to live out the covenant obligations
Pray for the strength to be a faithful steward of God's blessings, especially in supporting the vulnerable

chapters.chapterTitle: The Altar on Ebal; Curses Pronounced

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 27:1-26 aloud, focusing on the Levites' declaration of curses in verses 22-23 and the people's response in verse 26.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'this day' in verses 1-2 to emphasize the present moment
Pay attention to the emotional weight of the people's 'Amen' responses (v.26)
The phrase 'the stone that is uncut' (v.2) symbolizes God's unchanging covenant

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Levites and people of Israel) does WHAT (proclaims the curses and accepts them), WHERE (on Mount Ebal), and WHY (to ensure the new generation adheres to the law).
tips: The Levites stand as the representatives of the law (v.8)
The altar of uncut stones is built on Mount Ebal (v.2)
The twelve curses are pronounced for secret sins that break the covenant (v.14-26)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Levites' precise declaration of curses (v.22-23), the people's unified 'Amen' (v.26), or the symbolic altar of uncut stones (v.2).
tips: The Levites' declaration of the twelve curses is meticulous and covers every area of sin (v.22-23)
The people's response of 'Amen' (v.26) shows collective commitment and corporate confession
The altar made of uncut stones (v.2) represents God's unchanging and permanent covenant with Israel

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about the law and their relationship with God through this passage?
tips: Moses is ensuring that the new generation internalizes the law by making it tangible and binding through a physical marker (the stones and altar) and a public declaration
This passage emphasizes that the law is not abstract but must be lived out in community and with accountability
The curses are a warning that breaking the covenant has serious consequences, but the people's 'Amen' shows they are willing to accept the law's authority

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The specific list of curses, the role of the Levites, or the meaning of 'uncut stones'?
tips: The twelve curses cover a range of sins that were common in ancient Israel (e.g., idolatry, injustice) but some may seem harsh by modern standards
The term 'uncut stones' (v.2) refers to stones that have not been shaped by human hands, symbolizing the permanence of God's covenant without human alteration
The Levites are chosen to pronounce the curses because they are set apart for holy service (Deuteronomy 19:15-21) and represent the community's accountability

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the concept of corporate confession (the people saying 'Amen') apply to your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you've been silent about a sin that affects the community (e.g., injustice to others)
Pray for the courage to confess a hidden sin to a trusted friend or leader
Commit to being part of a group that proclaims the law (like the Levites) by helping others in the community

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the covenant and ask for the courage to confess and obey the law.
tips: Thank God for the unchanging covenant that He establishes with us through Christ (as the curses point to Christ bearing the curse)
Pray for the strength to confess hidden sins and to live in community with integrity
Ask God to help us build altars of uncut stones in our lives—where we stand firm in His truth without compromise
