questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 29:1-29 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'this day' and the phrase 'the secret things belong to the LORD'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'this day' (v.1, v.2, v.3)
Pay attention to the phrase 'the secret things belong to the LORD' (v.29) and 'the revealed things are for obedience' (v.29)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Moses addresses, WHAT the covenant entails, WHERE this happens (Moab), and WHY this renewal is necessary for the new generation.
tips: Include that the new generation has never seen the plagues or the Exodus
Note that the covenant is a second renewal (after Sinai) to ensure they understand they are under God's law
The setting is in Moab, where they are about to enter the Promised Land

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the phrase 'this day' (v.1), the warning against following heart's idols (v.14), or the phrase 'the secret things belong to the LORD' (v.29).
tips: The phrase 'this day' (v.1) emphasizes the present moment of covenant commitment, not a future promise
The warning: 'You shall not follow your heart's idols' (v.14) is a direct call to avoid idolatry in the new generation
The phrase 'the secret things belong to the LORD' (v.29) highlights that God's true nature is beyond human understanding

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God and the covenant?
tips: Moses emphasizes that the new generation must understand that they are under God's covenant and not free to worship idols
The covenant is inclusive of all (the new generation) and requires total commitment to God
This covenant renewal is the foundation for entering the Promised Land without the sin of idolatry

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'second covenant', the phrase 'secret things', or the idea that the new generation must understand without prior experience of the Exodus?
tips: 'Second covenant' (v.10): This refers to the renewal of the same covenant with the new generation after the Exodus
'Secret things belong to the LORD' (v.29): This means that some aspects of God's character and purposes are beyond human comprehension
The new generation has no prior experience of the Exodus (unlike the previous generation) so they must be taught the covenant

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can we apply the theme of 'the revealed things are for obedience' to our lives this week?
tips: Choose one commandment from God's revealed law that you can live by without adding your own conditions
Ask God to help you avoid following your own heart's idols (v.14) in your decisions this week
Practice being open to God's covenant renewal in your life, as the new generation was

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for renewing His covenant with us and for the gift of understanding (the Spirit). Ask for the strength to obey the revealed things without adding idols.
tips: Thank God for the covenant renewal and for the Spirit who opens blind eyes (as in Christ's work)
Pray for the heart to be circumcised (as in the New Covenant) so that we can truly follow God
Ask God to help us avoid the sin of idolatry by focusing on the revealed things (God's commands)

chapters.chapterTitle: Restoration and the Choice of Life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 30:1-20 aloud, focusing on the contrast between God's promise of restoration and the call to choose life.
tips: Notice the phrase 'circumcised hearts' (v.6) as a symbol of internal transformation
Pay attention to the repetition of 'choose life' (v.19) and 'choose death' (v.19) for emphasis
The emotional tone shifts from hope (v.1-5) to urgency (v.11-14) and then to the consequence (v.15-20)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is promised restoration, WHAT God commands, WHERE this occurs, and WHY the new generation must choose life.
tips: Include the scattering of Israel (v.1) and the promise of restoration (v.3-5)
Note the call to return to the LORD with all their heart (v.2) and the circumcised hearts (v.6)
Mention the command being near (v.14) and the choice between life and death (v.19)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's promise of restoration (v.3-5), the circumcised hearts (v.6), or the choice of life (v.19)?
tips: The promise of restoration after scattering is especially comforting (v.3-5)
The phrase 'circumcised hearts' (v.6) is a powerful image of the internal change God brings
The simplicity of the command being 'in your mouth and heart' (v.14) challenges the idea that God's requirements are far away

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God's promise of restoration and the choice of life?
tips: Moses is reminding them that God's promise of restoration is available if they choose to return to Him
The circumcised heart (v.6) is the key to true obedience, not just external actions
The command is not too far (v.14) but accessible to the new generation in their current state

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'circumcised hearts', the absolute nature of 'choose life or death', and the accessibility of God's command?
tips: 'Circumcised hearts' refers to the internal transformation by the Holy Spirit (as in Christ connection), not a physical act
The choice between life and death (v.19) is not about physical life but about the consequences of obedience to God
The command being 'near' (v.14) means it's accessible in the heart and mouth, not requiring external rituals

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you choose life by having God's command in your mouth and heart (v.14) this week?
tips: Identify one area where you are choosing death (e.g., sin, unbelief) and choose life by obeying God's command
Practice having the command of God in your mouth and heart by reading and meditating on Scripture daily (v.14)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the theme of restoration and the choice of life as presented in Deuteronomy 30.
tips: Thank God for His promise of restoration for the new generation (v.3-5)
Ask for the grace to have a circumcised heart (v.6) and to choose life (v.19) over death
Pray for the courage to obey God's command in the midst of life's challenges

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 31:1-29 aloud, paying attention to the transition from Moses to Joshua in verses 1-2 and the command to write the song in verses 14-15.
tips: Notice the phrase 'be strong and courageous' (v.6) repeated in the commissioning
Pay attention to the song as a 'witness' (v.14) and the warning about rebellion (v.17-18)
The phrase 'the new generation' (v.1) is key to the audience

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being commissioned, WHAT Moses commands, WHERE this happens, and WHY it is important for the new generation.
tips: Moses (at age 120) commissions Joshua (v.1-2)
Moses writes the law for the Levites to read every seven years (v.18-19)
Moses writes a song as witness for future rebellion (v.14-15)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Joshua's appointment (v.1-2), the song as witness (v.14-15), or the command 'be strong and courageous' (v.6)?
tips: The immediate transfer of leadership without delay (v.1-2) shows God's plan for continuity
The song is a living testimony that will be taught to future generations (v.14-15) - it's a 'witness' against rebellion
The command 'be strong and courageous' (v.6) is a direct call to the new generation to trust God

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God through this passage?
tips: Moses is preparing the new generation for leadership by ensuring they have the law and the song as a witness
The song is a prophetic warning to prevent rebellion after Moses' death
The new generation must be strong and courageous to follow God's law

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The purpose of the song, the seven-year reading cycle, or the warning about rebellion?
tips: The song is not just a song but a 'witness' (Hebrew: shema) - it serves as testimony against future rebellion
The seven-year cycle for reading the law is a practice of the Temple (to remind the people of the covenant) and not a random timing
The warning about rebellion (v.17-18) is a direct prediction of what will happen if they don't follow the law

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be 'strong and courageous' (v.6) in your life this week?
tips: Write a short 'song' (a testimony or declaration) to share with someone or to remember God's faithfulness in a specific area
Identify one situation where you need to be strong and courageous and ask God for the strength to act

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the new generation to be strong and courageous, to follow God's law, and to remember the song as a witness.
tips: Thank God for providing Joshua (the leader) and the song (the witness) for the new generation
Ask for courage to be strong and courageous in your daily challenges
Pray that we don't rebel but follow God's law in our lives

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 32:1-43 aloud, focusing on the metaphors of God as the Rock (v. 3-4) and the description of Israel's ungratefulness (v. 19-20).
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'God is the Rock' (v. 3-4)
Pay attention to the emotional contrast between God's care (v. 10-11) and Israel's rebellion (v. 19)
Listen for the tone of warning and hope in the conclusion (v. 35-43)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God is, WHAT He does for Israel, WHERE this song was written, and WHY Moses is writing it to the new generation.
tips: Include God as the Rock (v. 3-4)
Note Israel's rebellion in the wilderness (v. 19-20)
Describe God's future vindication (v. 35-43)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God carrying Israel as an eagle (v. 10-11), Israel's 'growing fat' and forsook God (v. 19), or God's future vengeance (v. 35).
tips: The eagle metaphor (v. 10-11) shows God's protective care, which contrasts with Israel's unfaithfulness
The phrase 'grew fat and forsook Him' (v. 19) is a powerful image of spiritual complacency
The declaration of God's vengeance and vindication (v. 35-43) provides hope for future restoration

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God through this song?
tips: Moses warns that God is the Rock (v. 3-4) and that if they turn away (like the previous generation), God will judge them and then vindicate His people (v. 35-43)
This is a call to remember God's faithfulness and to avoid becoming a 'crooked generation' (v. 1:11)
The song foreshadows the future where God will avenge and vindicate His people (v. 35-43)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The term 'crooked generation' (v. 11), the meaning of 'provoke' (v. 35), or the concept of 'vindication' (v. 35)?
tips: 'Crooked generation' (v. 11) refers to a generation that is morally corrupt and unfaithful, not a literal physical crook
'Provoke' (v. 35) means God will bring a foolish nation (Gentiles) to challenge Israel, but in the end, He will vindicate His people
'Vindication' (v. 35) means God's final justice and restoration of His people after their rebellion

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's faithfulness to your life this week, especially when you feel like you are 'growing fat' (v. 19) in your spiritual life?
tips: When you feel complacent in your faith, ask God to remind you of His ongoing care (like the eagle)
Surrender a specific area of your life that you are holding onto (as Israel did) to God
Pray for the new generation (including yourself) to remember God as the Rock (v. 3-4)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being the Rock (v. 3-4) and ask for the grace to not become ungrateful like Israel.
tips: Thank God for His faithfulness as the Rock (v. 3-4)
Pray for courage to avoid becoming a 'crooked generation' (v. 11)
Ask God to help you remember His provision (like the eagle) when you feel ungrateful

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 33:1-11 aloud, paying attention to the distinct blessings for each tribe and the closing phrase.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the God of Jeshurun' in the closing (verse 11)
Pay attention to the specific blessings for Reuben, Judah, Levi, Benjamin, Joseph, and the other tribes
The phrase 'There is none like the God of Jeshurun' (verse 11) emphasizes God's uniqueness

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Moses) does WHAT (blesses the tribes), WHERE (in the wilderness, as he prepares to die), and WHY (to establish the tribes' identities and God's provision for them).
tips: Include that Moses is blessing the new generation of Israelites
Note the specific blessings for Reuben, Judah, Levi, Benjamin, Joseph, and the other tribes
The blessing for Joseph (v.10) is particularly significant as he is the most prominent tribe

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the blessing of Judah (verse 7), the blessing of Joseph (verse 10), or the closing phrase (verse 11)?
tips: Judah is the tribe that will rule the nations (verse 7) - this is a foreshadowing of Christ
Joseph's blessing: 'Abundant blessing of heaven and earth' (verse 10) - showing his importance in God's plan
The closing phrase: 'There is none like the God of Jeshurun' (verse 11) - emphasizing God's uniqueness and faithfulness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites through this passage?
tips: Moses is setting the tribes' identities and their roles in God's plan
The blessing of Judah points to Christ (the Messiah)
The phrase 'God of Jeshurun' (the upright one) emphasizes God's character and His provision for the people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The blessing of Reuben, the meaning of 'Urim and Thummim', and the phrase 'God of Jeshurun'?
tips: Reuben is the firstborn tribe but his blessing is 'may he live' - this might seem odd because he was cursed for his sin
Urim and Thummim are sacred objects used by the Levites for divine guidance (they were the 'oracle of God')
Jeshurun means 'the upturned' or 'the just one' in Hebrew, but in this context it refers to the people of God (the chosen nation)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of God's provision for each tribe. How can you apply this to a specific area of your life this week?
tips: Think about how God has provided for you in a way that is specific and unique (like a tribe)
Consider sharing your blessing with someone who needs encouragement
Pray for the blessing of the tribe that you are part of (e.g., Judah, Joseph, etc.)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He is the God of Jeshurun and that He blesses each tribe. Ask for the same blessing in your life.
tips: Thank God for His provision for each tribe
Pray for the tribe that you are part of (e.g., Judah, Joseph, etc.)
Ask God to help you live as a blessing to others

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Deuteronomy 34:1-12 aloud, focusing on the contrast between Moses' vision and his death.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the LORD showed him the whole promised land' (v.4)
Pay attention to the detail that Moses' eye was not dim and his vigor was not gone (v.7)
Highlight the phrase 'no one knows his grave' (v.6)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters for the new generation of Israelites.
tips: Moses sees the promised land but does not enter it
He dies at 120 years old in Moab
God buries him in an unknown location

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Moses' vision of the land (v.4), his death at 120 (v.7), or the unknown grave (v.6)?
tips: Moses seeing the land without entering - a powerful contrast to the new generation's future
The fact that Moses died at 120 with no physical decline - showing God's care for him
The mystery of the grave: God's plan for Moses' burial is beyond human understanding

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the new generation of Israelites about God's faithfulness and the transition of leadership?
tips: Moses' death is not a failure but a completion of his mission
God's promise to the land is secure for the new generation
Joshua is prepared by God to lead, showing that God's wisdom is present in the next generation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The exact cause of Moses' death? Why is the grave unknown? What does it mean for Joshua to be 'filled with the spirit of wisdom'?
tips: The text doesn't specify the cause of death, but emphasizes his strength until the end
The unknown grave points to God's mystery and the fact that human efforts to find graves are futile
'Filled with the spirit of wisdom' (v.10) is a divine gift, not natural wisdom

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of seeing the promised land without entering it to your life? What does it mean for you to be in the 'land of promise' but not yet in the 'rest'?
tips: Consider the promises God has made to you that you haven't yet experienced
Reflect on how the law (which we are under) points to Christ, the one who brings us into the rest
Practice waiting on God for the full realization of His promises

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for Moses' faithful leadership and for the transition to Joshua. Ask for wisdom in your own life.
tips: Thank God that Moses saw the land but did not enter it, showing His faithfulness to the promise
Pray for the new generation to trust God's provision for the land
Ask God to fill you with wisdom as Joshua was, so you can lead others in faith
